urn:contentItem:5JRR-JX81-F0N8-R034-00000-00Doors open on planned burns2016-05-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:54ZLexisNexisNEWSDoors open on planned burns

The Environment Department is encouraging central Victorian residents to share their local knowledge and become involved in the fire operations plan for the Murray Goldfields fire district through two 'open houses'.

Department of Environment, Land, Water and Planning Murray Goldfields district manager Paul Bates said he was keen to hear community members' views on fire management.

'I would encourage the community to come and speak to our forest fire management staff at one of two open houses to discuss the plans, which outline the frequency and location of planned burns, and the three year schedule of burns and mulching, slashing and grooming activities planned for Central Victoria,' he said.

'By engaging our communities, utilising their local knowledge and combining it with Phoenix Rapidfire technology, the simulation software we use to predict the spread and intensity of bushfires, we can be more strategic in our planning.

'This will ensure our fuel reduction activities occur in areas which will most effectively reduce the impacts of bushfire on human life and property.'

Mr Bates said once the department determined the location of a planned burn, it was added to the draft fire operations plan which was open for community comment.

'The plan lists all fuel reduction activities, including burning, slashing, grooming, mulching and fuel breaks that will take place over the next three years,' he said.

'Reducing bushfire fuel means fires are less intense, making it more likely that firefighters can contain them before they impact on people, property and the environment.'

The first open house is on Tuesday, May 24 at the Bendigo Town Hall between 2pm and 7pm and features a presentation on box ironbark landscape mosaic burning.

The second open house will be at the Ray Bradfield Room in Frederick Street, Castlemaine between 2pm and 7pm on Wednesday, June 1.

The plan can be viewed at www.delwp.vic.gov.au/burns

urn:contentItem:5TYG-1W11-JD34-V08B-00000-00Following a fire's trail2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:54ZLexisNexisFollowing a fire's trailChris Pedler

Tracing a bushfire back to its point of origin is a skill emergency service organisations are becoming extremely well versed in.

Fifteen trainee investigators added the valuable skill to their arsenals in Castlemaine this week.

At a session run by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the Country Fire Authority, trainees searched for clues and patterns from "suspicious fires" set by course instructors in a previous planned burn site.

FFMVic statewide fire investigation and training co-ordinator Les Vearing said bushfire investigation was an important and highly-skilled job.

"Bushfire investigators work out the cause and origin of bushfires and, with larger bushfires, they can determine the path and impact of the fire," he said.

"(That information) can also help determine if it the same fire is burning through a 20- or 30-kilometre long area (or if it is multiple fires)."

Along with tracing burn patterns and fire-based clues back to a point of origin, trainee investigators were able to study active fires to learn about how they move.

"We don't often learn a lot about fire behaviour (while battling blazes)," Mr Vearing said. "Out here we are able to conduct live burns, which is something unique for firefighters. Normally, we are used to racing out and putting the fire out as quickly as we can.

"Doing live burns allows us to study the fire, particularly the early stages and how it moves with the wind, the topography or the fuel types involved with it.

"We can watch how it moves past barriers on the ground like rocks, bricks or trees.

"It's something we do in both grassland and forest areas, which show different indicators and are different types of burns."

Mr Vearing said it was essential trainees received practical training on a real fire ground.

"Trainees will figure out where the fire started, what caused ignition and which way the fire spread," he said.

"The key to fire investigation is finding the point of origin because it usually contains the clues to show whether ignition was natural, an accident or deliberate.

"Course participants will be on hands and knees looking for clues such as staining on rocks, burn patterns on trees, tyre tracks or signs that someone has been using machinery, a chainsaw or other hand tools such as angle grinders."

CFA bushfire instructor Brett Wagstaff, who helped run the course, said indicators of a fire were key to learning more and developing fire investigation skills.

"In the art of fire investigation, there are a number of things we look for in burn and char patterns," he said. "The more fire we investigate, the more we learn.

"We have been investigating bushfires in Victoria for more than 20 years now. We learnt a lot after the Black Saturday fires and there is always new technology we can employ and new things to learn."

A number of different emergency service organisation took part in this week's training course, including the CFA, FFMVic, Metropolitan Fire Brigade and members of Victoria Police's arson and forensic squads.

Mr Vearing said the co-operation between emergency service organisations had improved dramatically since Black Saturday.

"It's great, the way we work together in Victoria. It doesn't always work (like that) in other states," he said.

"Even before Black Saturday we didn't have the same level of co-operation between agencies (like we do today).

"The co-operation now is great. In a large bushfire we need to work together. Since Black Saturday, our strength has increased and and we work extremely well together.

"Often (FFMVic or CFA) work out where a fire started and police come in and work out who it was started by.

"In the last few years we have been very successful in tracking down a number of arsonists."

urn:contentItem:5NWY-9B01-F0JP-W15S-00000-00GLOBAL SNAPSHOT2017-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 17GLOBAL SNAPSHOT

1 Fire nears heritage site MADRID: A forest fire in southern Spain forced the evacuation of at least 1000 people and threatened a national park famous for its biodiversity and endangered species, authorities said on Sunday. The fire started on Saturday night on Spain's southern coast, then advanced east to reach the Donana Nature Reserve, one of the country's most important wildlife sanctuaries and a UNESCO World Heritage site since 1994. The reserve protects over 107,000ha considered of extreme ecological value for their mix of ecosystems, including wetlands, dunes and woods.

2 Explosion toll rises LAHORE: The death toll from a tanker explosion in Pakistan has climbed to at least 153. Dozens more are in a critical condition, hospital and rescue officials said. The tragedy on Sunday was sparked by an announcement over a mosque's loudspeaker that an overturned tanker truck had sprung a leak. Scores of villagers then raced to the scene with fuel containers to gather the oil. Then the wreck exploded, engulfing people in flames as they screamed in terror.

3 Pharmacy boss guilty BOSTON: The co-founder of a Massachusetts compounding pharmacy is set to be sentenced in a deadly nationwide meningitis outbreak that killed more than 60 people and sickened hundreds more. Barry Cadden was acquitted of second-degree murder charges under federal racketeering law, but convicted on conspiracy and fraud charges. Sentencing is scheduled for Monday in federal court in Boston.

Cadden was charged in connection with a 2012 fungal meningitis outbreak that was traced to contaminated injections of medical steroids made by the New England Compounding Centre in Framingham. Prosecutors say Cadden ran the centre in a dangerous way by skirting industry regulations on sterility in an effort to push production and make more money.

4 Disney map goes for $1mLOS ANGELES: The original colour map of Disneyland, used by Walt Disney to win funding for his first theme park, has been sold for almost $A1 million. The 1953 artefact became the most lucrative Disneyland map when it went under the hammer for $US708,000 ($A935,480) in Los Angeles on Sunday, according to the auctioneers. It had been hidden away for more than 60 years after the cartoonist gave it to a production assistant. Van Eaton Galleries co-owner Mike Eaton said: "After some pretty exciting bidding the map sold for $US708,000, making it the most expensive Disneyland map ever sold."

xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>FOREST FIRE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MADIGAN M</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">KEYWORD-HIT</p><p nitf:lede="true">FEATURES</p><p nitf:lede="true">PAGE 15</p><p nitf:lede="true">THIS VERSION</p><p nitf:lede="true">V ETERAN Queensland Green Drew Hutton sees a yawning philosophical c</p><p nitf:lede="true">hasm opening between</p><p nitf:lede="true">the state's conservation movement and the man best-placed to</p><p nitf:lede="true">represent its interests, Environment Minister Brian Littleproud.</p><p nitf:lede="true">That fundamental difference, according to Hutton, inevitably will</p><p nitf:lede="true">result in acrimony, dissent and ""enormous confrontation" between the</p><p nitf:lede="true">powerful environment lobby and the Borbidge Government.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Conservationists believe the environment should be protected, with</p><p nitf:lede="true">the primary role of national</p><p nitf:lede="true">parks being to guard and nurture bio-diversity.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Hutton says the state's latest Environment Minister sees national</p><p nitf:lede="true">parks as venues for letting people get out to ""enjoy the bush".</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>""It's a yawning philosophical divide between this Government and</p><p>the conservation movement, and it is a divide the Government is going</p><p>to have to cross," he said.</p><p>This week's announcement that State Cabinet would consider a</p><p>proposal to allow private enterprise</p><p>to operate camping grounds and other facilities within national</p><p>parks was a blunt illustration</p><p>of the size of the ideological gulf separating the increasingly</p><p>hostile camps.</p><p>The previous Goss Labor administration</p><p>faced several similar protests during its tenure, the most</p><p>controversial being its backing of the Skyrail project linking the</p><p>tourist village of Kuranda</p><p>to the northern outskirts of Cairns, an enterprise which now</p><p>attracts almost universal acclaim</p><p>.</p><p>But with the spectre of the Bjelke-Petersen years still clinging to</p><p>the new-look Borbidge administration</p><p>, greens are becoming concerned that Littleproud will open the</p><p>floodgates to another chapter of environmental thuggery.</p><p>The claim that he was set to clean out the Wet Tropics Management</p><p>Authority and stack it with sympathetic members was, according to</p><p>Hutton, an even more powerful indication than the privatising of</p><p>national parks that the Government was intent on a bold new agenda.</p><p>Littleproud's office dismissed that accusation as ""fanciful",</p><p>saying the two board vacancies would be filled in keeping with the</p><p>Government's commitment to a policy of openness.</p><p>Wet Tropics board member Aila Keto won't comment on Littleproud's</p><p>performance or recent</p><p>media comments, preferring to say that within the current legal</p><p>framework the State Government, with the Federal Government, was</p><p>obliged to administer</p><p>World Heritage Authority legislation.</p><p>Dr Keto believed a change in legislation would be required if the</p><p>Government appointed new board members who significantly altered the</p><p>Authority's direction.</p><p>""Our statutory obligation is only to protect the Wet Tropics,"</p><p>she said. ""We are not sanctioned to satisfy as a matter of priority</p><p>any development interests."</p><p>She also said that Australia had an obligation to protect areas of</p><p>outstanding heritage value. ""It just seems to me to put in dams in</p><p>these places _ and the Minister is on the record as wanting to put in</p><p>dams, power lines and roads in the wet tropics _ is an extraordinarily</p><p>worrying proposition."</p><p>In blunter language, Hutton said any attempt to stack the board</p><p>would result in a bloody battle between the Government and the state's</p><p>environmental lobby.</p><p>""Any attempt to stack the board with compliant members will just</p><p>be the touchstone to all-out war."</p><p>Like almost all key figures in the conservation movement, Hutton</p><p>believed the new agenda was not so much a sinister attempt</p><p>to return to the ""good old days" of environmental insensitivity</p><p>as a lack of understanding of the issues.</p><p>He said the role of the Environment Minister in Cabinet should be</p><p>played out along traditional lines, with the Minister displaying a</p><p>determination to protect and enhance the interests within the</p><p>portfolio. Just as a minerals and energy minister would lobby for a new</p><p>power station, or enhance</p><p>existing units, environment ministers should be fighting for the</p><p>betterment of national parks and the environment, he said.</p><p>But in Hutton's view, the Minister was heading in the opposite</p><p>direction.</p><p>Despite that criticism, Littleproud retains a fair degree of</p><p>goodwill among many in the environmental movement.</p><p>Queensland Greens convenor Angela Jones, albeit disappointed by</p><p>recent signs of ""bad faith", pointed to the Minister's good start in</p><p>addressing waste management.</p><p>She said conservationists across the state also were relieved</p><p>that a review of the Environmental Protection Act had left it</p><p>virtually intact.</p><p>Littleproud is surprised and apologetic at the perception that he</p><p>is philosophically at odds with conservationists, most of whom he holds</p><p>in high esteem.</p><p>""I'm sorry there is a belief there is a rift developing," he said</p><p>yesterday, adding that his first few months in the job had been taken</p><p>up with addressing practical management and resource issues</p><p>within national parks.</p><p>That focus, along with his public comments on those issues, perhaps</p><p>created the incorrect perception he was not supportive of the wider</p><p>""big-picture" agenda.</p><p>Hutton, he said, held ""very sincere" views, while society owed a</p><p>debt to the activism of people of Hutton's ilk, who over the past two</p><p>decades had drawn attention to the pressing need for environmental</p><p>reforms.</p><p>But the Minister said the public had to keep in mind the wider</p><p>picture: while most conservationists could snipe from a relatively</p><p>comfortable position of unelected representation, he had to address a</p><p>much wider agenda. ""We are going to have development in this state and</p><p>my job is to ensure it is environmentally sustainable development," he</p><p>said.</p><p>He will meet Federal Environment Minister Senator Robert Hill today</p><p>to discuss proposed changes to the Wet Tropics Authority</p><p>.</p><p>D ESPITE the Minister's assurances of good faith, Angela Jo nes</p><p>believes his Government had been positively deceitful in stating its</p><p>position on national parks.</p><p>She pointed out that in the lead-up to the Mundingburra poll, the</p><p>Coalition had made a show of concern about the lack of available</p><p>funding for national parks, and the poor management of those parks the</p><p>previous Labor government had purchased.</p><p>Yet just months into power the Coalition had drafted plans to</p><p>introduce</p><p>private enterprise to the national park sphere without even a</p><p>pretence of consultation.</p><p>""On the real green issues they are definitely going back on</p><p>promises they made before the election," she said. ""The fact is, the</p><p>Government's constituency will naturally push it in a certain</p><p>direction."</p><p>Queensland Conservation head Roger Kitching has proved reluctant to</p><p>say anything about the Environment Minister's performance ""for fear of</p><p>incriminating myself", preferring to point out that the apparent</p><p>radical environmental</p><p>agenda was not necessarily backed by a mandate.</p><p>""You've got to remember they are only there by a whisker," he</p><p>said, remarking that the new Minister had made few friends _ ""he</p><p>certainly got the environment movement offside from Day One but that</p><p>could be more to do with his manner than anything else". He was also</p><p>unhappy with the policy direction.</p><p>Privatisation of national parks was only one issue and not, in</p><p>itself</p><p>, an unacceptable idea, he said.</p><p>But the concern was that fundamental elements of national park management fell into private, and inexperienced hands.</p><p>""A national park is a public resource</p><p>and it is society which determines how it is used," he said.</p><p>""Politicians mess with it at their peril."</p><p>CONFLICTING views . . . Dr Aila Keto, above, Brian Littleproud, top</p><p>right and Drew Hutton . . . more questions than answers.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PMW-4G81-JD34-V449-00000-00Australia baked in unprecedented early-season heat2017-10-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:54ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 7Australia baked in unprecedented early-season heatPeter Hannam

Last month's early-season bursts of heat sent temperatures of some parts of eastern Australia a full 16 degrees above average, new analysis by the Bureau of Meteorology shows.

In a Special Climate Statement examining two pulses of extreme warmth that seared large areas of inland Australia from Victoria to Queensland, the bureau identified the many national and statewide September records that tumbled.

While associated with large high-pressure systems, the bureau noted global warming had pushed up the background temperatures by about a degree over the past century for Australia and the planet as a whole, making the occurrence of such extreme events more likely.

"Studies undertaken by the bureau and other scientific institutions have shown that climate change has contributed to the severity and frequency of recent heat events, including spring warmth," it said.

The special report comes a day after new research showed Australian cities such as Melbourne and Sydney need to prepare for summer days when the temperature climbs to 50 degrees in decades to come - even if nations kept to Paris climate pledges to keep global warming to less than 2 degrees.

The bureau's report also noted that unusually dry conditions contributed to the recent abnormal heat.

The recent significant heat emerged on September 21, with almost all the country recording above-average temperatures, the bureau said.

Australia as a whole recorded its warmest September day on record the following day, with a mean maximum temperature of 33.47 degrees.

That was more than 6 degrees warmer than the September average, and eclipsed the previous September record of 33.39 degrees set in September 1998.

Victoria posted its hottest September reading on September 23, with Mildura clocking a 37.7 reading.

The ongoing lack of rain in many regions has meant less cloud cover and available soil moisture to be evaporated, helping to drive daytime temperatures higher.

The bureau's latest drought statement, released on Wednesday, showed rainfall deficiencies are intensifying in inland regions.

There is some hope for better rainfall in the weeks ahead, including signs that the Pacific is tilting towards La Nina conditions.

During La Nina events, eastern Australia tends to have above-average rainfall, although cyclones also tend to increase in frequency in the Australian region.

Before the change, though, farmers and firefighters are in for an anxious few weeks, if not longer.

As the bureau's special report noted, dangerous fire conditions emerged during the recent heatwaves, including during the shorter second wave at the end of September.

According to the McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index, values exceeded extreme levels at many sites around the country from September 22-27, the bureau said.

urn:contentItem:5XJ9-1HM1-DXP7-14V1-00000-00Climate change will make fire storms more likely in southeastern Australia2019-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:38:54ZLexisNexisClimate change will make fire storms more likely in southeastern AustraliaGiovanni Di Virgilio, Research associate, UNSW

Extreme fire risk will overlap with weather patterns to create fire tornadoes more often under climate change.

Temperatures across many regions of Australia are set to exceed 40? this week, including heatwaves forecast throughout parts of eastern Australia, raising the spectre of more devastating bushfires.

We have already heard warnings this fire season of the possibility of firestorms, created when extreme fires in the right conditions form their own weather systems.

Read more: Firestorms and flaming tornadoes: how bushfires create their own ferocious weather systems

Firestorms are the common term for pyrocumulonimbus bushfires - fires so intense they create their own thunderstorms, extreme winds, black hail, and lightning.

While they are very rare, our research published earlier this year, found climate change is making it likely they will become more common in parts of southeast Australia.

We also identified certain regions in southern and eastern Australia, including near Melbourne's fringe, that in the second half of this century will be far more vulnerable to these events than others.

How firestorms happen

The 2003 Canberra bushfires, devastating on a grand scale, saw a Canberra resident film a fire tornado for the first time ever. Six years later, the ferocious Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria created   three separate pyrocumulonimbus events.

More recently, fire storms devastated California in November 2018.

Pyrocumulonimbus events begin with the intense heat of a very big and fast-burning wildfire, which causes a large and rapidly rising smoke plume. As the plume rises, low atmospheric pressure causes it to expand and cool. Moisture can condense into a type of cloud known as a pyrocumulus - not pyrocumulonimbus, yet. This type of cloud can be common in large fires.

However, with the right environmental conditions the plume goes much higher and pyrocumulonimbus clouds can form, towering up to 15km in some cases. As it rises, the plume cools, and the upper part of the clouds form ice particles that collide and can produce lightning.

These thunderstorms can create erratic and dangerously strong wind gusts. These can drive blizzards of embers that ignite spot fires beyond the fire font.

Lightning from the plume can start new fires, well ahead of the main fire. In one case, lightning generated in a pyrocumulonimbus cloud has been recorded starting new fires up to 100km ahead of the main fire.

How climate change makes firestorms more likely

One of the key elements to a firestorm forming is the precondition of the atmosphere above it. We wanted to investigate how a changing climate might affect the likelihood of firestorms happening.

Previous research has found there is more dynamic interaction between a large fire and the atmosphere when the air about 1.5km above the surface is relatively dry, and when there are larger temperature differences across increasing altitudes.

The larger the temperature difference, the more unstable the atmosphere may become. When higher altitudes get cold more quickly than normal, and are also very dry at low levels, it can become more likely that a pyrocumulonimbus event will develop during a large fire.

We used high-resolution climate modelling of projected lower atmospheric instability and dryness conditions to assess the risk of pyrocumulonimbus in southeastern Australia between 2060 and 2079, compared with 1990-2009. We then overlaid this information with the forest fire danger index to identify particularly dangerous fire days.

We were then able to identify how often dangerous fire weather days occurred at the same time as a dry and unstable atmosphere. Verifying our models against past observations, we then examined how often these two characteristics coincided in the future under climate change, should our greenhouse gas emissions remain on their current trajectory.

The results were startling. From 2060 onwards, we saw sharp increases in dangerous fire days across southeast Australia that coincided with atmospheric conditions primed to generate firestorms.

These extremely dangerous days also shifted across seasons, starting to appear in late spring, whereas historically Australian pyrocumulonimbus wildfires have typically been summer phenomena.

Across large areas of Victoria and South Australia, on average, we saw four or five more days every spring that were conducive to pyrocumulonimbus events.

Read more: A surprising answer to a hot question: controlled burns often fail to slow a bushfire

These were sobering findings, even in a land of extremes like Australia. Our research suggests human-caused climate change has already resulted in more dangerous weather conditions for bushfires in recent decades for many regions of Australia. These trends are very likely to increase due to rising greenhouse gas emissions.
